rComments: Hands down the best professor I've ever had. Sure, if you have no interested in the subject taught or you want to get through by doing as little as possible, then don't take this class.

The most boring and incompetent professor at SC. He's passed off basic questions he says he didn't know to the TAs. He gives really vague lectures and mumbles so that even on a mic, people have trouble hearing him. You'll do well if you have a good ta. His class is so terrible people either sleep or do hw for other classes in his class.

I can honestly say that Sahota was the worst professor I've ever had. His class consisted of random lectures that had little to do with what we read about. He assigned random and pointless readings which he disparagingly abandoned. He bombarded us with lectures that hated on the canon and he spoke in an ignorant way.
The lectures and essay prompts were extremely confusing and the professor rarely responded to emails.

I hated this class. The professor's lectures had no aim whatsoever and he was really hard to understand. Your grade is made up of 3 essay grades and that is all, so your grade relies entirely on your TA. Definitely try and avoid Sahota if you have to take this class.

Come close, dear lit majors. 3 essays make up your grade. Rely on your TA, because you will not get much out of his ramblings and inaudibility (he speaks soft and doesn't use the mic correctly). Let's put it this way: by week 4, everyone started bringing books to class to read to tune out his lecture. Seems nice, but terrible, terrible lecturer.

UGH! Very hard to follow (rambles without providing any discernible focus for the lecture), doesn't follow the syllabus he provided at all. Whatever you do, try to take Translation Theory with a different prof if you can, even if it's over the summer.

The readings are dense as hell, and the professor cannot even explain them clearly. I have been coming to every lecture, and I still don't feel like I'm learning anything. Essay prompts are very confusing. He should not be a lecturer in my opinion--I can barely hear him, and he wears a microphone!  Thankful for my TA; without her I'd be lost!

This class is nothing like an English class in high school and that is why I loved it. Lectures were not about the plot of the epics, they were about the significance and relevance of the epic, linguistics, history, etc. I'll admit that the lectures were hard to pay attention to at times, but always worthwhile. Essay prompts were a bit confusing.

We never discussed literature in a class about ancient epics. We talked about the indo-european proto language and way more history on the books than necessary. We never got into the symbolism of the literature itself. He could not answer questions. Gave me a lower grade for not quoting his favorite scholars.
